title: HTML Forms
subject: HTML
learning_objectives: Learn about action and method attributes (GET vs POST)
theory:
# HTML Forms

An HTML form is used to collect user input. The user input is most often sent to a server for processing.

## The `<form>` Element

The `<form>` element is a container for different types of input elements, such as text fields, checkboxes, radio buttons, submit buttons, etc.

```html
<form action="/submit" method="POST">
  <!-- Inputs go here -->
</form>
```

## Key Attributes

### 1. `action`
Defines **where** to send the form-data when the form is submitted (the URL of the server script).
*   Example: `action="/login.php"`

### 2. `method`
Defines **how** to send the data.
*   **GET**: Appends form data to the URL (visible in address bar). Used for search forms. NOT secure.
*   **POST**: Sends form data in the request body (invisible). Used for passwords, login, uploading files. Secure.

## Labeling

The `<label>` tag defines a label for form elements.

*   **Accessibility:** Screen readers read the label when the user focuses on the input.
*   **Usability:** Clicking the label focuses the input field.

**Binding Label to Input:**
Match the `for` attribute of the label with the `id` of the input.

```html
<label for="username">Username:</label>
<input type="text" id="username" name="user">
```

examples.code:
<form action="/search" method="GET">
  <label for="q">Search:</label>
  <input type="text" id="q" name="query">
  <button type="submit">Go</button>
</form>
examples.output: A search box and a Go button.

common_mistakes.correction: If an input field doesn't have a name attribute, its value will NOT be sent to the server.
Inputs without labels are bad for accessibility.
common_mistakes.example: Always pair input with label using for/id.

interview_questions.question: What is the difference between GET and POST?
interview_questions.answer: GET appends data to the URL (visible, length limit, bookmarkable). POST sends data in the HTTP body (invisible, no size limit, secure). GET is for fetching data; POST is for submitting data.

interview_questions.question: Why is the name attribute important in forms?
interview_questions.answer: The server uses the 'name' attribute as the key to identify the data value submitted. Without it, the data is not sent.

practice_problems.problem: Create a login form with username and password fields which submits to '/login' via POST.
practice_problems.solution:
<form action="/login" method="POST">
  <label for="u">User:</label>
  <input type="text" id="u" name="username">
  <label for="p">Pass:</label>
  <input type="password" id="p" name="password">
  <input type="submit" value="Login">
</form>

real_world_use_cases.description: Every signup page uses a POST form to securely transmit user details to the backend database.

exam_notes: Input 'name' is required for server processing
summary: Forms are the primary way users interact with websites. The <form> element wraps input controls and specifies how (GET/POST) and where (Action) data is sent. Accessibility starts with proper use of <label> tags bound to inputs.
